Award.AwardTitle: Single Cell and Subcellular Analysis by Laser Ablation Electrospray Ionization Mass Spectrometry
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award by the Chemical Measurement and Imaging (CMI) program supports work by Professor Akos Vertes at George Washington University - endowed to develop an analytical platform for investigating metabolism changes in single cells and in subcellular regions. This project aims to extend the reach of laser-based sampling techniques to enable the mass spectrometric analysis of single animal and human cells for the investigation of a vast array of biological problems. Prerequisites for this goal include the sufficient focusing and delivery of the laser radiation to the region of interest, improving the overall sensitivity of the method, extending the coverage of metabolites and lipids present in the cell, determining the chemical integrity and quantity of the sampled ions, and enabling high throughput single cell analysis. The PI also aims to explore the in situ analysis of subcellular domains within larger cells by combining micromanipulation and microdissection with laser sampling and mass spectrometry. Successful accomplishment of these goals will bring the capabilities of single cell mass spectrometry to a new level.

In a broader sense, the PI and his group develop new single cell and subcellular analysis tools and methods that enable the study of diverse biochemical processes relevant for chemistry and the life sciences. Due to the ability of the tools they are creating to address various unresolved problems, the research itself has a significant potential to benefit society. Integration of research and education in the project is closely tied to the direct involvement of K-12, undergraduate and graduate students in the process of scientific inquiry. Based on their existing and planned collaborations with industry, the students will also have an opportunity to be immersed in the conversion of new research results into methods and devices that are applicable in various fields relevant to society, including biomedicine, energy and homeland security. To broadly disseminate his research, the PI plans to engage the media to reach the general public and explain their results in an easily digestible format.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit

Information on the chemical composition within a cell has implications for the understanding of cell metabolism, disease states and ecological effects. Cells of the same type exhibit diverse metabolic makeup depending on genetic regulation and interactions with the environment. Analysis of the metabolites in a single cell is challenging because of the limited size and complexity of the sample. We have developed a novel chemical measurement method, laser ablation electrospray ionization (LAESI), for in situ metabolite profiling of single cells and subcellular regions. The technique is based on microscopic sampling by mid-infrared laser ablation followed by electrospray ionization (ESI). The generated ions are analyzed by mass spectrometry (MS). The LAESI-MS technique enables the direct analysis of cells, without sample processing. Thus the studied cells are unperturbed and their metabolite content reflects their biological state right before analysis.

Ablating the sample within a capillary is shown to significantly reduce radial expansion of the ejected material, ensuring more overlap between the ablation plume and the electrospray. This results in enhanced ionization efficiency, lower limits of detection, and a wider dynamic range than conventional LAESI. Ion mobility separation (IMS), used in combination with LAESI-MS, allows further distinction of chemical species for the identification of isobaric metabolites and structural isomers. IMS coupled with LAESI-MS is demonstrated for the analysis of single plant cells, such as tissue embedded epidermal cells with expanded molecular coverage.

A second single cell method, microcapillary sampling is adapted to analyze small cells approaching ~15 μm in size. Metabolic profiles are obtained by capillary microsampling and ESI in combination with IMS-MS.  Different epidermal cell types, including pavement and basal cells, and trichomes, are analyzed in a plant leaf. The comparison of ion intensities indicates systematic differences in the related metabolite levels of the three cell types and provides insight into cellular heterogeneity.

Subcellular variations in metabolite concentrations result from the presence of organelles and active transport inside the cell. Cell dissection, in combination with LAESI-MS, provides a first look at the distribution of metabolites between the nucleus and cytoplasm.

Mass spectrometry imaging is a rapidly emerging technology for the mapping of molecular distributions in tissues. Cell-by-cell imaging is demonstrated using LAESI-MS, where individual cells are selected to serve as natural pixels for tissue imaging. We have developed a method for a novel cell-by-cell LAESI imaging approach that automates cell recognition and addressing for systematic ablation of individual cells in a tissue. Cell types with particular morphologies are also selected for analysis. The feasibility of high throughput cell-by-cell molecular imaging of plant tissues by LAESI-MS is demonstrated.

Broader impacts

New tools for chemical measurement: Chemical measurements have a broad impact on major societal issues ranging from human health to sustainability. During the grant period, we have developed several novel tools that help to answer fundamental questions in cell biology, in particular the metabolomic analysis of single cells and subcellular compartments. By developing a high throughput version of cell-by-cell tissue imaging by LAESI-MS, a new approach became available for the metabolic analysis of heterogeneous tissue embedded cell populations. Capillary microsampling combined with ESI-IMS-MS for single cell analysis results in a new tool for the detection of hundreds of molecular species. This has broad implications for other disciplines, including plant sciences and cell biology....
